document.text: WILEY H. ROBERTSON Funeral services for Wiley Hogue Robertson, 87, were con ducted at 2 p.m. Sunday at Ro binson Funeral Home with bur ial in the Old Concord Presby terian Church Cemetery. A retired postmaster and mer chant, he died at 330 a.m. F ri day in his home at Spout Spring. He was the husband of thelate Rosa Bondurant Robertson. Born in Appomattox County, he was the son of Calvin Ro bertson and EllaShear eiRobert- son. He was the father of the late Appomattox County Sheriff David T. Robertson. He was an elder of Old Concord Presby terian Church. He is survived by two sons, Shearer B. Robertson of Spout Spring and W. Howard Robert son of Altavista three daugh ters, Mrs. Theodore Carson of Altavista, Mrs. Joe H. Asher of Brookneal and Mrs. Burt Broom of Atlanta, Ga. one brother, J. O. Robertson of Spout Spring, nine grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.

The meeting adopted two resolutions one endorsing Watkins M. Abbitt for renomination and re-election to Congress from the Fourth District, introduced by Calvin Robinson and one endorsing the record of United States Senator Harry F. Byrd, in troduced by C. W. Smith. Congressman W. M. Abbitt was present and addressed the meeting. Charles F. P. Crawley served as the presiding officer of the meeting and C. W. Smith served as secretary. document.text: week H. H. Caldwell, Jr. entered the lists for this office. Commonwealth Attorney It is presumed that the incumbent, G. F. Abbitt, Jr. will file and will be the only candidate. County Treasurer J. Garland Plunkett and Thomas T. Martin ape the announced candidates. David T. Robertson, the incum bent sheriff, was appointed to fill out the term of the late H. W. Mc Kinney, and four years ago won a full term. He was opposed in that election four years ago by Vernell Mitchell. Sheriff Robertson inform ed The Times-Virginian this week that he would be a candidate, and to date no other has announced. The two-way race for Commission er of the Revenue will find H. H. Caldwell, Jr. opposing the veteran incumbent, J. H. OBrien. Mr. Cald- will be making his first bid for public office. He is the son of H. H. Caldwell, of Route 3, Appomattox. He graduated at Appomattox High School in 1943 and entered the Navy as Aviation Cadet August 10 of that year. While in the service he took special courses at the Universities of South Carolina and Georgia. He served on the USS. Bismarck Sea, and was on same when the carrier was sunk by a Jap dive bomber at tack Feb. 23, 1945. He was among the rescued survivors. He entered V. P. I. in the fall of 1945, and re ceived his B. S. degree in 1949. He was president of the civilian student foody his senior year. Since he has been employed with American To bacco Co., Schaffer Pen Co., and since 1954 with Gary Steel Products Corp, Lynchburg, as assistant to the general sales manager..

document.text: Tuesday, Nov. 8, is General Election day in Virginia, and a last minute effort is being made to get out a sizeable vote for Appomattox County. There are approximately 2,500 eligible voter in the county, but thus far there has been a min imum of interest, and the size of the actual vote is uncertain. To be elected are unopposed candi dates for the State Senate and the House of Delegates, and a slate of unopposed nominees for county of fices. Polling places will open at 6 A. M. and close at 6 P. M. There are ten precincts in the county. The candidates, all Democrats, are as follows For the State Senate, Chas. T. Moses. For the House of Delegates John B. Boatwright. For Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt, Jr. For County Treasurer John G. Plunkett. For Commissioner of the Revenue J. H. OBrien. For Sheriff David T. Robertson. For Supervisor in Southside Dis trict F. L. Murphy. For Supervisor in the Stonewall District Otho W. Martin, Jr. For Supervisor in the Colver Hill District Richard Webb. For Justice of the Peace, South- side District Cree to be elected T. W. Moses, Mrs. Lucille S. Con ner and E. T Guill. The officials to be elected Tues day will take office in January. In appealing for a good turn-out of voters next Tuesday, the quality of the candidates listed and the im portance of the eounty maintaining a record for a large vote, were cited as reasons for everyone making an effort to cast their ballots.

document.text: To Tho, Voters of Appomattox County Governor Darden, at the direc tion. of the legislature, has fixed MaNffi. 6, 1945, as the, date to hav a Special election in ..Virginia, up on the question of whether or not the members of our armed force shall be allowed to vpte without pqying a polf .tax or Registering. hp regular Vdifing places will be open as uspal from sunrise to sun set. . As you know there are nearly 109 boys and girls in the armed ,t,rCSpram Appomattox County. Many of them are serving across he ocean thousands of mile- from vie. A number of them will nev- -?.r return. Some are already sleep- ? in lonely graves without a single loved one near to place flowers upon their grave. Others e rsking their lives daily that we might remain at home with our loved ones. Still others have lost their sight, lost arms, legs and other injuries too horrible to men tion. All in the service have gone where they were directed to go and served where told to serve whether on this side of the ocean  or on the other side. They are all doing their duty as commanded. The question is shall we allow these who are fighting and dying for us the privilege to vote or whether we will refuse them this privilege. It is not a question of whether they desire to vote. It is a question of whether they shall have the right to vote if they so desire. We do not believe that any patriotic citizen of Appomattox County, knowing the facts, would intentionally deprive our boys and girls of this great privilege. .veryone who was eligible tt ote last November in the Presi dential election is eligible to vote March 61 In addition all those who have paid 1942, 1943 and 1944 taxes by December 12, 1944 are also eligible to vote taking tax receipts with them to the polls o show election judges. We ear- .estly request every qualified vot er to go to your voting precinct and vote on March 6, 1945, and back our boys and girls. Let them know that we in Appomattox County are behind them in every way............ Signed W. M. Abbitt, George bbitt, Jr., Mrs. S. L. Ferguson, L. F. Ferguson, G. B. Buchanan, R. L. Burke, David T. Robertson. H. W. McKinney, Mrs. Calvin H. Robinson, D. A. Conner Chas. T. Moses.

document.text: There are four contests awaiting the decision of the voters. In Stonewall Magisterial District there is a three-way race for the office of supervisor. Incumbent John P. Alvis, Jr., is being opposed by O. W. Martin, Jr., and Hpbert B. Scruggs. Over 800 votes are expect ed at the three precincts in Stone wall District. Veteran incumbent James H. OBrien is being opposed for nomi nation for another-term as Commis sioner of the Revenue by H. H. Caldwell, Jr. - Incumbent David T. Robertson is being opposed for Sheriff by J. Alex Bingham, a retired State Police Lieutenant. Deputy Treasurer John Garland Plunkett and Thomas Terrill Martin, are vieing for the nomination for County Treasurer. These contests have been the oc casion of active campaigns, both by the contestants and their friends. Many letters have been mailed to the voters and personal appeals have kept all hands on the go fonthe past three months. Predictions as to the outcome de pend on which side you question, but the overa-all conclusion is that there will be a heavy vote and that at least some of the contests will be close. Most contestants are preparing their workers for a major effort on1! election day and will try to see that no eligible voter fails to go to the polls. There are ten voting precincts in Appomattox County. Election offi cials, aeording to a list secured by this newspaper yesterday, will be as follows Court House Precinct Judges J. H. Lucado, L J. Mor ris and J. W. Durrum. Clerks Mrs. L. L. Stanley and Mrs. Lou C. Rog ers.

A first probability is an inersass in draft calls by the Selective Service. For some time, thé calls for this county have been only one dr .. tee per monjtih. Re enlistments of those already in the armed serv ices have kept at a normal level the number of men from this county in the various services. t It is now likely, it is believed, the draft calls will be at least doubled. The county has a fairly long list of men in the available group. The calls for those who take armed force physical examinations may be increased. .. As a further possible development the Civil Defense Progjram is likely b be stepped up, John Cole is the Civil .Defense chairman for Appomattox County, haring succeeded the late Sheriff Kv . .. 4 . - - David T. document.text: The Appomattox County Draft Board has received a call for seven men to be sent for physical exami nation within ten days. The call is on Virginias quota of 500 men un der re-activated Selective Service. The county board will meet Mon day and will select the men for the call from the 25 year old group. The county board is composed of A. R. Harwood, Jr., H. A. Gurney and David T. Robertson. All are veterans of World War II. It-is not known yet whether the men will go to Roanoke or Rich mond for examination. The board requests that all regis trants notify the board of any change in their classification status since registration papers were filled out. Mrs. C. Lewis McDearmon is secretary to the board, now on a full time basis, with offices in her home in Appomattox.

document.text: SPOUT SPRING  Mrs. Rosa Bondurant Robertson, 78, died Monday night in Lynchburg Gen eral Hospital. She was born in j Nelson County, the daughter of David Thomas and Willie Em- I ma Carter Bondurant. She was a member of the Old Concord Presbyterian Church at Spout Spring. Survivors include her husband, Wiley Hogue Robertson two sons. Shearer B. Robertson, of Spout Spring and W. Howard Ro bertson, of Altavista three daughters, Mrs. Theodore Car- son, of Altavista, Mrs. Joe H. Asher, of Brookneal and Mrs. Bert Broom, of Pompano Beach, Fla. two brothers, Wallace Bon durant and T. J. Bondurant, both of Concord one sister, Mrs. Ida Stratton, of Concord nine grand children and two great - grand children. She also was the mother of the late Sheriff David T. Robertson of Appomattox County. Funeral services were held at 3 p.m. Wednesday at Robinson Funeral Home in Appomattox. Burial was in the Old Concord Presbyterian Church Cemetery.

document.text: Sheriff David T. Robertson an nounced this week that he has ap pointed two part time deputies to assist in extra police duties in the county. They are Walter Phelps, at Oakville, who will act as jail guard in the absence of the jailer, and Thomas G. Catlett at Pamplin, who will serve papers, both criminal and civil, and other general law enforce ment work in the jPamplin area. .Mrs. Walter Phelps was also ap pointed Justice of the Peace, for Stonewall District, and will act as Justice of the Peace in the absence of Mrs. Walter Conner from the jail and Mrs. Vaida L. Catlett, wife of the new Pamplin deputy, will be Jus tice of the Peace for the Pamplin area, Clover Hill District. Sheriff Robertson states that Mr. and Mrs. Catlett were appointed es pecially to help the people of the Pamplin area and on request of the Town Council of Pamplin. The sheriff states that there will be no allowance for any salary for these appointees from the county treasurer, but the Justices will be paid on. a fee basis at no cost to the county, and the new deputies will receive pay according to what they do and the cases they work on, such to be approved by the sheriff and the county board of supervisors at the end of each month and the state will pay two-thirds of this amount. The fees collected by the new deputies and paid into the county treasury will offset the balance of the one- third to be paid by the county.

document.text: Santa Claus has accepted an in vitation from the Lions Club to visit Appomattox this Saturday, Decem ber 22, and will arrive in town by Jeep at 2 00 P. M. Arrangement have been made to close Main Street to oil other traffic dlunng his visit, and on area be tween the Farm era National Bank and Inges Dept. Store wtill be roped off for Santas headquarters, while he distributes gifts and candy to the children. Railings will be set up along the sidewalk, so that children con be channeled in lane for their meeting with the distinguished visi tor. The Appomattox Loons Club has had committees at work on this pro ject for some weeks. Included on the committee are Dr. C. G. OBrien, J. H. Lucado, Joe Teesry, Joe Flen- iken, and  David T. Robertson. The Transco officials and employees are cooperating with the Lions Club committee. The annual visit of Santa Clous to Appomattox is a highlight of the Christmas season, and the event has traditionally been sponsored by the lions Club.

document.text: Pictures on dishes, trays, and oth er decorative, ornamentative, and useful ware is not a new idea but the way David T. Robertson has evolved 3 new and apparantly it is destined to make up much of the productive output o f his concern. A sample of this new product is illustrated above, together with an illustration of decorative use of the product. The picture, used for this illustration is that of onC of Appo mattoxs most attractive homes.that of Mrs. S. L. Ferguson. The repro duction on a large serving platter is in beautiful color and truly a show piece. In his first experiments, Mr. Rob ertson has successfully used his process to put pictures of individ uals, homes and outdoor scenes on china and ether ware, some in black and white and others in color. The product is not yet on the market, but Mr. Robertson states that he hopes to get into production on the Item at the earliest possible time, j Experts who have seen his work de- I dare it to have tremendous com- 1 mercial possibilities.

document.text: OLD CANNON NEVER DIE  Old cannot never die, you just re mount them on a new carriage. For many years, since the time of the late Congressman Hal Flood, two- Civil War cannon have been display ed in the courtyard here. They ac tually were Federal and not Con federate in their history. Months ago Sheriff David T. Robertson noted the deteriorated condition of the carriages, and suggested to the coun ty board of supervisors that the car riages be rebuilt. The work was done in Pamplin, and has now been com pleted. So this item on the court house should be good for a new lease on life.

document.text: Often the practice of souvenir hunting is a good thing, but Appo mattox County has sent out a plea for the return of some souvenirs. During last Fridays visit from the Hurricane Hazel, several large trees in the court house yard here were uprooted and fell over on the historic Confederate Monument in the court house square. The monu ment was broken into many pieces as it toppled from its pedestal. A number of the pieces are missing. They may have been picked up by souvenir hunters. If so, the county begs that they be returned, so that the monument may be reconstructed sufficiently to have a mold made for casting a replacement. Shireff David T. Robertson is custodian for coun ty property.

document.text: Nearly 800 ballots were cast in Appomattox Countys ten precincts in Tuesdays General Election, as all Democratic nominees were elect ed without opposition. The vote wa3 considered a fairly good showing in the light of lack of opposing candi dates and was slightly ahead of the total vote in last years general elec tion. J. H. OBrien, commissioner of the revenue, topped the voting with a total of 73 b ballots, closely follow ed by J. Garland Plunkett with 736 for county treasurer. The big court house,precinct here- was just short of 300 votes cast. State Senator Chas. T. Moses was re-elected to another four-year term, receiving 718 ballots in the county. Delegate John B. Boatwright receiv ed 665. Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt Jr. received 692 votes, sheriff David T. Robertson 693,and the 3 unopposed candidates for supervisor, F. L. Murphy, Otho Matrin Jr. and R. M. Webb received 320, 213, and 186 votes respectively. Interest over the state centered in a few contests for the State Senate and House of Delegates, where Re publican or Independent carididates sought to win over Democrats. In most cases the Democrats won, al though Ted Dalton was returned to the State Senate and gained pres tige for another possible bid for the Governorship.
